The name of Lake Wendouree (in Australia) comes from a local aboriginal word wendaaree which means 'go away': a story is told that when settler William Cross Yuille asked a local indigenous woman what the name of the water body was, that was her reply. some language-PL-TOP design-ACCOMP-WHICH person difficult many language-PL dirtunderfingernails difficult many.
possibility all language 1PS.3PO-?-PL imagine-CAN-WHICH design-ER

Great video, loved it. The calling signs arbitrary  is a bit misleading. The signs for rabbit (in the examples) and the sounds of 'burp' etc aren't  arbitrary (in any conventional sense) because of their symbolic or onomatopoeic correspondence to the thing they are referring to. A not-completely-photorealistic picture isn't arbitrary. But this is great. Thank you!

Three things.
Great course, looking forward to new episodes. As a Spanish speaking person, I can say that there's not a translation for "looking forward" that conveys its meaning exactly.
Second, people who study animal behaviour could disagree about them not understanding words. I have read of parrots literally telling jokes and laughing at them, to the great amazement of their owners.
Third, the thing about people in the same family language having different vocabulary is very true. Chilean here, quarantining in Argentina. Still learning the local names for nearly everything. Sigh. Be warned, whoever is learning Spanish, if you are doing it in order to travel somewhere, try to get texts and videos from that country. Specially Chile. An American wrote a dictionary of Chilean slang properly titled "How to Survive in the Chilean Jungle." 😂

9:33 I´m assuming Correct Language is equivalent to Standard Language here.

The fact is that English is the glaring exception here. Other cultures value Standard Language more than English speakers in the sense that they value the homogeneity and protection it provides. It allows better communications and language integration, as well as education. Some people associate "evolution" as "progress", when in reality they are not equivalent. it can also mean degradation, in the sense that makes the language to lose communicative capabilites. Who has to decide which is which? That´s of course a valid question.

Some examples of highly standardized languages are Spanish, French and German, just to name a few wide spread languages. Less spoken or local language can be even more standardized as they look for extra protection against language degradation and disintegration, like Basque, Guarani, Cherokee, etc

Right at the end, you touch upon a very important thing to understand: Often there is no single, direct translation from one word in one language to one word in a different language.

This is because often words have multiple related (but different) meanings, and in a different language those meanings might have each their own words.

As an example, take the word "date", which has several meanings in English:
1) (noun) a reference to a day and possibly year: 2020-09-12
2) (verb) the act of assigning an age, period or date(1) to an object: He dated the find to 70CE.
3) (noun) a social event with a partner - often of a romantic nature.
4) (noun) the partner taken on a date(3).
5) (verb) the act of going on a date(3) with a date(4).

And sometimes there are even words that are written identically to other words, such as:
6) (noun) a kind of fruit.

Just because those first 5 meanings use the same word in English, there's no good reason to assume they will be using the same word in another language. And the fruit is very unlikely to have a similar name to anything related to calendars or scheduling.

Emojis aren't their own language, of course. They're a shared part of existing languages. Or... wait, are ideograms not considered a part of language? But I would argue that emojis definitely have reflexivity. I mean, it's definitely harder and rarer, but people have made comments about emojis, using emojis, like showing that they hate an ugly emoji by pointing a gun emoji at it. People do it all the time. Here. This is using emojis to talk about the appearance of emojis:

🍎📱🙂👀🙅🤢
🤖📱🙂👀👍💖

Or, here is a hypothetical conversation talking about what an emoji means:

Alex: 🎥🍿
Blake: 🙏
Alex: 🦧🙏😕
Blake: 😂
Blake: ✋➡️👏⬅️🤚
Blake: 🙏
Alex: 😮
Blake: 🤭
Alex: 😡
Alex: 📱🔣😖
Alex: 🤔🙏🙇🥺
Blake: 🙅🥺🙇
Blake: 👏
Alex: 😓👍
Blake: 🎥🍿🙏👍
Alex: 🙏
Blake:😉

Of course, what an emoji seems to mean may depend on the device it's read on... Like, the twitter orangutan is not scratching its head. Plus, there are only so many emojis, and it's more nebulous, and sometimes harder to parse, but you absolutely, definiitely can use emojis to talk about emojis. It's just definitely a whole lot easier to use more rigorous and precise language. Of course, maybe reflexivity has a more narrow meaning that this video didn't touch on. Idk. But I mean... Emojis definitely are used as language. Right???

For practical every day use and for practical and pragmatic use in the study of linguistics, it makes sense to call signs arbitrary, as tracing a word all the way back to it's roots at the dawn of human evolution is nigh impossible. However, i do sometimes wonder if language or signs, truly are arbitrary, or if our earliest ancestors actually did have some kind of system, pattern or reasoning behind the naming of things, acts and concepts.

Perhaps our physical interactions with the world and our perception and experince of the world through our body and it's senses helped shape our signs and language. The physical properties of a rock for example, it's shape, size, colour, texture, weight, temperature and so on, might've informed the naming of the object in a way that isn't "just" arbitrary.

The experience of touching a rock, holding it, throwing it, getting hit by it, hearing the sounds it makes when interacting with the ground, other rocks, our own species, etc could maybe have lead us to a naming convention with a logic to it. While experience is very subjective, certain elements persist between different people, animals and whatever else that might posses the ability to experience things, so perhaps these persistent elements, grounds language and signs in/to something "real" rather than arbitrariness.

Now just to be clear, i don't have a vendetta against arbitrariness, i don't mind things being arbitrary, i just think it's fun to speculate about alternative possibilities.

I’m excited that you guys are making a course on linguistics, but I’ve seen in both the trailer vid and this introductory video, you’re suggesting linguistics is all about studying the language as it is and not as it should be, but that’s not really the whole picture.

Descriptivist linguists do indeed study language the way it is and spend no time discussing how they think it should be, but whether this is the right way to study language is an ongoing debate. The other side of the coin is prescriptivist linguistics: describing language and treating certain linguistic traits as better than others.

Now, prescriptivism has lost popularity over the years because it’s often discriminatory to say that a certain trait is better than another. Prescriptivism has driven many people to think certain dialects of standardized languages are somehow worse, or less deserving of respect, which is derogatory for speakers of the non-standard strains of a language.

However, prescriptivism is still a thing nowadays because sometimes it does prove necessary. Take Spanish, for example. Spanish is one of the relatively few languages that have grammatical gender, which has proven insulting, discomforting and/or troubling for many people. Not only does the general use of grammatical gender in Spanish often deny females any visibility, but it also makes Spanish unable to represent non-binary people. After realizing the social issues that grammatical gender poses, many movements lead by feminism, the LBTQ+ community and indigenous communities proposed changing the language ridding it from grammatical gender progressively, in the hopes of granting women and non-binary people more visibility and respect.

Studying such phenomenon almost requires some degree of prescriptivism, because linguists are often required to align themselves with the political views of their sponsors or employers. Sometimes, it would seem you have to favour some linguistic traits over others.

I myself prefer descriptivism over prescriptivism, but I think this is just too important of a debate to be ignored. So maybe don’t overshadow prescriptivism.

Just a note: A dog wagging its tail doesn't always mean it's happy!
Tail wagging can have quite different meanings, e.g. enthusiasm, nervousness, tension, hostility, interest.
Thinking and teaching that tail wag = happy (or friendly) dog often gets inexperienced people bitten.
So maybe not the best example.

Terry Ptatchett was a linguistics MASTER:

“The forest of Skund was indeed enchanted, which was nothing unusual on the Disc, and was also the only forest in the whole universe to be called -- in the local language -- Your Finger You Fool, which was the literal meaning of the word Skund.

The reason for this is regrettably all too common. When the first explorers from the warm lands around the Circle Sea travelled into the chilly hinterland they filled in the blank spaces on their maps by grabbing the nearest native, pointing at some distant landmark, speaking very clearly in a loud voice, and writing down whatever the bemused man told them. Thus were immortalised in generations of atlases such geographical oddities as Just A Mountain, I Don't Know, What? and, of course, Your Finger You Fool.

Rainclouds clustered around the bald heights of Mt. Oolskunrahod ('Who is this Fool who does Not Know what a Mountain is') and the Luggage settled itself more comfortably under a dripping tree, which tried unsuccessfully to strike up a conversation.”

A dog wagging its tail does not always mean that it's happy.

It depends on what angle the tail wags. A low wagging tail can express nervousness. I have a dog with aggression triggers and I have to watch her body language to gauge how she's doing: if she's comfortable, if she's nervous but has herself under control, or if she needs to leave this situation. When I first got her, I did not know that dog wags meant different things. Seeing the low wags gave me the impression she was doing fine when she wasn't. So yeah, that's some slightly dangerous misinformation there.

All that said, I'm going to love this series.

I'm surprised she didn't talk about Productivity as a design feature of language. Productivity in language is referencing the fact that we can use language to come up with an infinite number of meaningful words and sentences because of the complex grammatical tools we have to rearrange/add words in a sentence or use new words in sentences (like compound words) and be able to develop a new meaning from context. It differentiates language from other arbitrary symbols because we can constantly create new sentences and words with new meanings, rather than being stuck with an unchanging set of communicative gestures that can't be adapted to refer to increasingly complex ideas or new additions to the world (like new technology).

If anyone's interested, look up Hockett's design features of language for a longer list. It's a little outdated (one of his design features is the vocal-auditory channels, which wrongfully excludes signed languages), but it includes all the ones Taylor talked about. In my linguistics education, I've mostly heard of arbitrariness, productivity, and duality of patterning being the most important, but that's a subjective take. Glad this series is happening!
